notesStmt.note: Does not contain leaf mentioned in Hazlitt, having 10 lines of verse beginning "Fames Windy trump."
It should be observed that in the preface the bookseller speaks of this as the "second" collection of the kind issued by him.
This book was ordered to be burned May 8 [1656?] cf. Sotheby catalogue. Sotheby (Britwell sale) April 1, 1924.
Reproduction of original in Huntington Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: BEING A Collection of divers excel. lent pieces of Poetry, OF Severall eminent Authors.
LONDON, Printed by J. G. for Robert Pollard, at the Ben John≈øon's head behind the Exchange, and John Sweeting, at the Angel in Popes-head Alley.

p.hi:
THy grateful reception of our fir≈øt Collection hath induced us to a ≈øecond e≈ø≈øay of the ≈øame nature; which, as we are confident, it is not inferiour to the former in worth, ≈øo we a≈ø≈øure our ≈øelves, upon thy already experimented Candor, that it ≈øhall at lea≈øt equall it in its fortunate acceptation. We ≈øerve up the≈øe Delicates
by frugall Me≈ø≈øes, as aiming at thy Satisfaction, not Saciety. But our de≈øigne being more upon thy judgement, than patience, more to delight thee, than to detain thee in the portall of a tedious, and ≈øeldome-read Epi≈øtle; we draw this di≈øplea≈øing Curtain, that intercepts thy (by this time) gravid, and almo≈øt teeming fancy, and ≈øub≈øcribe,

lg.l: DEare Love let me this evening dye,
Oh ≈ømile not to prevent it,
But u≈øe this oportunity,
Or we ≈øhall both repent it:
Frown quickly then, and break my heart,
That ≈øo my way of dying
May, though my life were full of ≈ømart,
Be worth the worlds envying.
Some ≈øtriving knowledge to refine,
Con≈øume them≈øelves with thinking,
And ≈øome who friend≈øhip ≈øeale in wine
Are kindly kill'd with drinking:
And ≈øome are rackt on the' Indian coa≈øt,
Thither by gain invited,
Some are in ≈ømoke of battailes lo≈øt,
Whom Drummes not Lutes delighted.
Alas how poorely the≈øe depart,
Their graves ffill unattended,
Who dies not of a broken heart,
Is not in death commended.
His memory is ever ≈øweet,
All prai≈øe and pity moving,
Who kindly at his Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe feet
Doth dye with over-loving.
And now thou frown'≈øt, and now I dye,
My corps by Lovers follow'd,
Which ≈øtreight ≈øhall by dead lovers lye,
For that ground's onely hollow'd:
If Prie≈øt take't ill I have a grave,
My death not well approving,
The Poets my e≈øtate ≈øhall have
To teach them th' art of loving.
And now let Lovers ring their bells,
For thy poore youth departed;
Which every Lover els excels,
That is not broken hearted.
My grave with flowers let virgins ≈øtrow,
For if thy teares fall neare them,
They'l ≈øo excell in ≈øcent and ≈øhew,
Thy ≈øelfe wilt ≈øhortly weare them.
Such Flowers how much will Flora pri≈øe,
That's on a Lover growing,
And watred with his Mi≈øtris eyes,
With pity overflowing?
A grave ≈øo deckt, well, though thou art
Yet fearfull to come nigh me,
Provoke thee ≈øtraight to break thy heart,
And lie down boldly by me.
Then every where ≈øhall all bells ring,
Whil≈øt all to blackne≈ø≈øe turning,
All torches burn, and all quires ≈øing,
As Nature's ≈øelf were mourning.
Yet we hereafter ≈øhall be found
By De≈øtiny's right placing,
Making like Flowers, Love under ground,
Who≈øe Roots are ≈øtill embracing.

div.head: Of a Woman that died for love of a Man.

lg.l: NOr Love nor Fate dare I accu≈øe,
Becau≈øe my Love did me refu≈øe:
But oh! mine own unworthine≈ø≈øe,
That dur≈øt pre≈øume ≈øo mickle bli≈ø≈øe;
Too mickle'twere for me to love
A thing ≈øo like the God above,
An Angels face, a Saint-like voice,
Were too divine for humane choyce.
Oh had I wi≈øely given my heart,
For to have lov'd him, but in part,
Save onely to have lov'd his face
For any one peculiar grace,
A foot, or leg, or lip, or eye,
I might have liv'd, where now I dye.
But I that ≈øtriv'd all the≈øe to chu≈øe,
Am now condemned all to lo≈øe.
You rurall Gods that guard the plains,
And cha≈øt'neth unju≈øt di≈ødains;
Oh do not cen≈øure him him for this,
It was my error, and not his.
This onely boon of thee I crave,
To fix the≈øe lines upon my grave,
With lcarus I ≈øoare too high,
For which (alas) I fall and dye.
ONe night the great Apollo pleas'd with Ben,
Made the odde number of the Mu≈øes ten;
The fluent Fletcher, Beaumont rich in ≈øen≈øe,
In Complement and Court≈øhips quinte≈ø≈øence;
Ingenious Shake≈øpeare, Ma≈ø≈øinger that knowes
The ≈øtrength of Plot to write in ver≈øe and pro≈øe:
Who≈øe ea≈øie Pega≈ø≈øus will amble ore
Some three≈øcore miles of Fancy in an houre;
Cloud-grapling Chapman, who≈øe Aerial minde
Soares at Philo≈øphy, and ≈øtrikes it blinde;
Danbourn I had forgot, and let it be,
He dy'd Amphibion by the Mini≈øtry;
Silvester, Bartas, who≈øe tran≈ølatique part
Twinn'd, or was elder to our Laureat:
Divine compo≈øing Quarles, who≈øe lines a≈øpire
The April of all Poe≈øy in May,
Who makes our Engli≈øh ≈øpeak Phar≈øalia;
Sands metamorphos'd ≈øo into another
We know not Sands and Ovid from each other;
He that ≈øo well on Scotus play'd the Man,
The famous Diggs, or Leonard Claudian;
The pithy Daniel, who≈øe ≈øalt lines afford
A weighty ≈øentence in each little word;
Heroick Draiton, Withers, ≈ømart in Rime,
The very Poet-Beadles of the Time:
Panns pa≈øtorall Brown, who≈øe infant Mu≈øe did ≈øqueak
At eighteen yeares, better than others ≈øpeak:
Shirley the morning-child, the Mu≈øes bred,
And ≈øent him born with bayes upon his head:
Deep in a dump John Ford alone was got
With folded armes and melancholly hat;
The ≈øquibbing Middleton, and Haywood ≈øage,
Th'Apologetick Atlas of the Stage;
Well of the Golden age he could intreat,
But little of the Mettal he could get;
Three≈øcore ≈øweet Babes he fa≈øhion'd from the lump,
For he was Chri≈øt'ned in Parna≈ø≈øus pump;
The Mu≈øes Go≈ø≈øip to Aurora's bed,
And ever ≈øince that time his face was red.
Thus through the horrour of infernall deeps,
With equal pace each of them ≈øoftly creeps,
And being dark they had Alectors torch,
And that made Churchyard follow from his Porch,
Poor, ragged, torn, & tackt, alack, alack,
You'd think his clothes were pinn'd upon his back.
The whole frame hung with pins, to mend which clothes,
In mirth they ≈øent him to old Father Pro≈øe;
Of the≈øe ≈øad Poets this way ran the ≈øtream,
And Decker followed after in a dream;
Rounce, Robble, Hobble, he that writ ≈øo high big
Ba≈ø≈øe for a Ballad, John Shank for a Jig:
Sent by Ben John≈øon, as ≈øome Authors ≈øay,
Broom went before and kindly ≈øwept the way:
Old Chaucer welcomes them unto the Green,
And Spencer brings them to the fairy Queen;
The finger they pre≈øent, and ≈øhe in grace
Transform'd it to a May-pole'bout which trace
Her skipping ≈øervants, that do nightly ≈øing,
And dance about the ≈øame a Fayrie Ring.
WHen fir≈øt the Magick of thine eye
U≈øurpt upon my liberty,
Triumphing in my hearts ≈øpoyle, thou
Did≈øt lock up thine in ≈øuch a vow:
When I prove fal≈øe, may the bright day
Be govern'd by the Moones pale ray,
(As I too well remember) this
Thou ≈øaid≈øt, and ≈øeald'≈øt it with a ki≈ø≈øe.
Oh heavens! and could ≈øo ≈øoon that tye
Relent in ≈øad apo≈øtacy?
Could all thy Oaths and mortgag'd tru≈øt,
Bani≈øh like Letters form'd in du≈øt,
Which the next wind ≈øcatters? take heed,
Take heed Revolter; know this deed
Hath wrong'd the world, which will fare wor≈øe
By thy example, than thy cur≈øe.
Hide that fal≈øe brow in mi≈øts; thy ≈øhame
Ne're ≈øee light more, but the dimme flame
Of Funerall-lamps; thus ≈øit and moane,
And learn to keep thy guilt at home;
Give it no vent, for if agen
Thy love or vowes betray more men,
At length I feare thy perjur'd breath
Will blow out day, and waken death.
IF at this time I am derided,
And you plea≈øe to laugh at me,
Know I am not unprovided
Every way to an≈øwer thee,
Love, or hate, what ere it be.
Never Twinns ≈øo nearly met
As thou and I in our affection,
When thou weep≈øt my eys are wet,
That thou lik'≈øt is my election,
I am in the ≈øame ≈øubjection.
In one center we are both,
Both our lives the ≈øame way tending,
Do thou refu≈øe, and I ≈øhall loath,
As thy eyes, ≈øo mine are bending,
Either ≈øtorm or calm portending.
I am carele≈ø≈øe if de≈øpi≈øed,
For I can contemn again;
How can I be then ≈øurpri≈øed,
Or with ≈øorrow, or with pain,
When I can both love & di≈ødain?

div.head: The Red head and the White.

lg.l: COme my White head, let our Mu≈øes
Vent no ≈øpleen again≈øt abu≈øes,
Nor ≈øcoffe at mon≈øtrous ≈øignes i'th' no≈øe,
Signes in the Teeth, or in the Toes,
Nor what now delights us mo≈øt,
The ≈øign of ≈øignes upon the po≈øt.
For other matter we are ≈øped,
And our ≈øigne ≈øhall be i'th' head.
Oh! Will ‚Ä¢ Rufus, who would pa≈ø≈øe,
Unle≈ø≈øe he were a captious A≈ø≈øe;
The Head of all the parts is be≈øt,
And hath more ≈øen≈øes then the re≈øt.
This ≈øubject then in our defence
Will clear our Poem of non-≈øen≈øe.
Be≈øides, you know, what ere we read,
We u≈øe to bring it to a head.
Why there's no other part we can
Stile Monarch o're this I≈øle of man:
'Tis that that weareth Nature's crown,
'Tis this doth ≈ømile, 'tis this doth frown,
O what a prize and triumph 'twere,
To make this King our Subject here:
Believ'e, 'tis true what we have ≈øed,
In this we hit the naile o'th' head.
Your nailes upon my head Sir, Why?
How do you thus to villifie
The King of Parts, 'mong≈øt all the re≈øt,
Or if no king, methinks at lea≈øt,
To mine you ≈øhould give no offence,
That weares the badge of Innocence;
Tho≈øe blowes would far more ju≈øtly light
On thy red skull, for mine is white.
Come on yfaith, that was well ≈øed,
A pretty boy, hold up thy head,
Or hang it down, and blu≈øh apace,
And make it like mines native grace.
There's ne're a Bung-hole in the town
But in the working puts thine down,
A byle that's drawing to a head
Looks white like thine, but mine is red.
Poore foole, 'twas ≈øhame did fir≈øt invent
The colour of thy Ornament,
And therefore thou art much too blame
To boa≈øt of that which is thy ≈øhame;
The Roman Prince that Poppeys topt,
Did ≈øhew ≈øuch Red heads ≈øhould be cropt:
And ≈øtill the Turks for poy≈øon ≈ømite
Such Ruddy skulls, but mine is white.
The Indians paint their Devils ≈øo,
And 'tis a hated mark we know,
For never any aim aright
That do not ≈øtrive to hit the white:
The Eagle threw her ≈øhell-fi≈øh down,
To crack in pieces ≈øuch a crown:
Alas, a ≈øtinking onions head
Is white like thine, but mine is red.
Red like to a blood-≈øhot eye,
Provoking all that ≈øee't to cry:
For ≈øhame nere vaunt thy colours thus
Since 'tis an eye-≈øore unto us;
Tho≈øe locks I'd ≈øwear, did I not know't,
Were threds of ≈øome red petticoat;
No Bedlams oaker'd armes afright
So much as thine, but mine is white.
Now if thon'lt blaze thy armes Ile ≈øhew't,
My head doth love no petticoat,
My face on one ≈øide is as faire
As on the other is my haire,
So that I bear by Heraulds rules,
Party per pale Argent and Gules.
Then laugh not 'cau≈øe my head is red,
Ile ≈øwear that mine's a noble head.
The Scutcheon of my field doth beare
One onely field, and that is rare,
For then methinks that thine ≈øhould yeild,
Since mine long ≈øince hath won the field;
Be≈øides, all the notes that be,
White is the note of Cha≈øtity,
So that without all feare or dread,
Ile ≈øweare that mine's a maidenhead.
There's no Camelion red like me,
Nor white, perhaps, thou'lt ≈øay, like thee;
Why then that mine is farre above
Thy haire, by ≈øtatute I can prove;
What ever there doth ≈øeem divine
Is added to a Rubrick line,
Which who≈øoever hath but read,
Will grant that mine's a lawful head.
Yet adde what thou mai≈øt, which by yeares,
Cro≈ø≈øes, troubles, cares and feares,;
For that kinde nature gave to me
In youth a white head, as you ≈øee,
At which, though age it ≈øelfe repine,
It ne're ≈øhall change a haire of mine;
And all ≈øhall ≈øay when I am am dead,
I onely had a con≈øtant head.
Yes faith, in that Ile conde≈øcend,
That our di≈ø≈øention here may end,
Though heads be alwaies by the eares,
Yet ours ≈øhall be more noble peeres:
For I avouch ≈øince I began,
Under a colour all was done.
Then let us mix the White and Red,
And both ≈øhall make a beauteous head.
We mind our heads man all this time
And beat them both about this rime;
And I confe≈ø≈øe what gave offence
Was but a haires difference.
And that went too as I dare ≈øweare
In both of us again≈øt the haire;
Then joyntly now for what is ≈øaid
Lets crave a pardon from our head.
SHall I think becau≈øe ≈øome clouds
The beauty of my Mi≈øtri≈øs ≈øhrouds,
To look after another Star?
Tho≈øe to Cynthia ≈øervants are;
May the ≈øtars when I doe ≈øue,
In their anger ≈øhoot me through;
Shall I ≈øhrink at ≈øtormes of rain,
Or be driven back again,
Or ignoble like a worm,
Be a ≈ølave unto a ≈øtorm?
Pity he ≈øhould ever ta≈øt
The Spring that feareth Winters bla≈øt;
Fortune and Malice then combine,
Spight of either I am thine;
And to be ≈øure keep thou my heart,
And let them wound my wor≈øer part,
Which could they kill, yet ≈øhould I bee
Alive again, when plea≈øeth thee.
A Stranger coming to the town,
Went to the Flower-de-luce,
A place that ≈øeem'd in outward ≈øhew
For hone≈øt men to u≈øe;
And finding all things common there,
That tended to delight,
By chance upon the French di≈øea≈øe
It was his hap to light.
And le≈øt that other men ≈øhould fare
As he had done before,
As he went forth he wrote this down
Upon the utmo≈øt doore.
All you that hither chance to come,
Mark well ere you be in,
The Frenchmens arms are ≈øigns without
Of Frenchmens harms within.
NEver was humane ≈øoule ≈øo overgrown,
With an unrea≈øonable Cargazon
Of fle≈øh, as Aldobrandine, whom to pack,
No girdle ≈øerv'd le≈ø≈øe than the zodiack:
So thick a Giant, that he now was come
To be accounted an eighth hill in Rome,
And as the learn'd To≈øtatus kept his age,
Writing for every day he liv'd a page;
So he no le≈ø≈øe voluminous then that
Added each day a leaf, but 'twas of fat.
The choice≈øt beauty that had been devis'd
By Nature, was by her parents ≈øacrific'd
Up to this Mon≈øter, upon whom to try,
If as increa≈øe, he could, too, multiply.
Oh how I tremble le≈øt the tender maid
Should dye like a young infant over-laid!
For when this Chaos would pretend to move
And arch his back for the ≈øtrong act of Love,
He fals as ≈øoon orethrown with his own weight,
And with his ruines doth the Prince≈ø≈øe fright.
She (lovely Martyr) there lyes ≈øtew'd and pre≈øt,
Like fle≈øh under the tarr'd ≈øaddle dre≈øt,
And ≈øeemes to tho≈øe that look on them in bed,
Larded with him, rather then married.
Oft did he cry, but ≈øtill in vain to force
His fatne≈ø≈øe powerfuller then a divorce:
No herbs, no midwives profit here, nor can
Of his great belly free the teeming man.
What though he drink the vinegars mo≈øt fine,
They do not wa≈øt his fle≈øhy Apennine;
His paunch like ≈øome huge I≈øtmos runs between
The amarous Seas, and lets them not be ≈øeen;
Yet a new Dedalus invented how
This Bull with his Pa≈øiphae might plow.
Have you tho≈øe artificial torments known,
With which long ≈øunken Galeos are thrown
Again on Sea, or the dead Galia
Was rais'd that once behinde St. Peters lay:
By the ≈øame rules he this ≈øame engine made,
With ≈øilken cords in nimble pullies laid;
And when his Genius prompteth his ≈ølow part
To works of Nature, which he helps with Art:
Fir≈øt he intangles in tho≈øe woven bands,
His groveling weight, and ready to commands,
The ≈øworn Prinadas of his bed, the Aids
Of Loves Camp, nece≈ø≈øary Chambermaids;
Each runs to her known tackling, ha≈øts to hoy≈øe,
And in ju≈øt di≈øtance of the urging voyce,
Exhorts the labour till he ≈ømiling ri≈øe
To the beds roof, and wonders how he flies.
Thence as the eager Falcon having ≈øpy'd
Fowl at the brook, or by the Rivers ≈øide,
Hangs in the middle Region of the aire,
So hovers he, and plains above his faire‚ñ™
Ble≈øt Icarus fir≈øt melted at tho≈øe beames,
That he might after fall into tho≈øe ≈øtreames,
And there allaying his delicious flame,
In that ≈øweet Ocean propogate his name.
Unable longer to delay, he calls
To be let down, and in ≈øhort mea≈øure falls
Toward his Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe, that without her ≈ømock
Lies naked as Andromeda at the Rock,
And through the Skies ≈øee her wing'd Per≈øeus ≈øtrike
Though for his bulk, more that ≈øea-mon≈øter like.
Mean time the Nur≈øe, who as the mo≈øt di≈øcreet,
Stood governing the motions at the feet,
And ballanc'd his de≈øcent, le≈øt that ami≈ø≈øe
He fell too fa≈øt, or that way more than this;
Steeres the Prow of the pen≈øile Gallea≈ø≈øe,
Right on Loves Harbour the Nymph lets him pa≈øs
Over the Chains, & 'tween the double Fort
Of her inca≈øtled knees, which guard the Port,
The Burs as ≈øhe had learnt ≈øtill diligent,
Now girt him backwards, now him forwards bent;
Like tho≈øe that levell'd in tough Cordage, teach
The murall Ram, and guide it to the Breach.
LI≈øt you Nobles, and attend,
For here's a Ballat newly penn'd
I took it up in Kent,
If any ask who made the ≈øame,
To him I ≈øay the authors name
Is hone≈øt Jack of Lent.
But ere I farther pa≈ø≈øe along,
Or let you know more of my Song,
I wi≈øh the doores were lockt,
For if there be ≈øo ba≈øe a Groom,
As one informes me in this room,
The Fidlers may be knockt.
Tis true, he had, I dare prote≈øt,
No kind of malice in his bre≈øt,
But Knaves are dangerous things;
And they of late are grown ≈øo bold,
They dare appeare in cloth of Gold,
Even in the roomes of Kings.
But hit or mi≈ø≈øe I will declare
The ≈øpeeches at London and el≈øewhere,
Concerning this de≈øign,
Among≈øt the Drunkards it is ≈øaid,
They hope her dowry ≈øhall be paid
In nought but Clarret wine.
The Country Clowns when they repaire

div.head: In prai≈øe of a deformed woman.

lg.l: I Love thee for thy curled haire,

Venus her ≈øelf, &c.

HE that a Tinker, a Tinker, a Tinker will be,

Though he travells all the day,

Oh he's the man of mettle.
HIde, oh hide tho≈øe lovely Browes,
Cupid takes them for his bowes,

He lies pelting at my heart,

Wounded in the heart I live;
From their colour I de≈øcry,

They mourn for tho≈øe their glances ≈ølay;

This too ≈øhewes him deeply wi≈øe,

div.head: To my Lady of Carnarvon, January 1.

lg.l: IDol of our Sex! Envy of thine own!
Whom not t' have ≈øeen, is never to have known,
What eyes are good for; to have ≈øeen, not lov'd,
Is to be more, or le≈ø≈øe then man, unmov'd;
Deigne to accept, what I i' th' name of all
Thy ≈øervants pay to this dayes Fe≈øtival,
Thanks for the old yeare, prayers for the new,
So may thy many dayes to come ≈øeeme few,
So may fre≈øh ≈øprings in thy blew rivolets flow,
To make thy ro≈øes, and thy lillies grow.
So may all dre≈ø≈øings ≈øtill become thy face,
As if they grew there, or ≈øtole thence their grace‚ñ™
So may thy bright eyes comfort with their rayes
Th' humble, and dazle tho≈øe that boldly gaze:
So may thy ≈øprightly motion, beauties be≈øt part,
Shew there is ≈øtock enough of life at heart.
So may thy warm ≈ønow never grow more cold,
So may they live to be, but not ≈øeem old.
So may thy Lord pay all, yet re≈øt thy debtor,
And love no other, till he ≈øees a better:
So may the new year crown the old yeares joy,
By giving us a Girle unto our Boy;
I'th' one the Fathers wit, and in the other
Let us admire the beauty of the Mother,
That ≈øo we may their ≈øeverall pictures ≈øee,
Which now in one fair Medall joyned be:
Till then grow thus together, and howe're
You grow old in your ≈øelves, grow ≈øtil young here;
And let him, though he may re≈øemble either,

Let Ladies wagers lay, who≈øe chin is this,
Who≈øe forehead that, who≈øe lip, who≈øe eye, then ki≈øs
Away the difference, whil≈øt he ≈ømiling lies,

Sweet Babe! my prayer ≈øhall end with thee,
(Oh may it prove a Prophecy!)
May all the channells in thy veynes
Expre≈ø≈øe the ≈øeverall noble ≈øtraines,
From whence they flow; ≈øweet Sydney's wit,
But not the ≈øad, ≈øweet fate of it;
The la≈øt great Pembroke's learning, ≈øage
Burleigh's both wi≈ødome and his age;
Thy Grand≈øires hone≈øt heart expre≈ø≈øe
The Veres untainted noblene≈ø≈øe.
To the≈øe (if any thing there lacks)

La≈øtly, if for thee I can woo

div.head: The We≈øtern Husband-man's Complaint in the late Wars.

lg.l: UDs bodykins! Chill work no more:
Do≈øt think chill labour to be poor?
No ich have more a do:
If of the world this be the trade,
That ich mu≈øt break zo knaves be made,
Ich will a blundering too.
Chill zel my cart and eke my plow,
And get a zword if ich know how,
For ich mean to be right:
Chill learn to zwear, and drink, and roar,
And (Gallant leek) chill keep a whore,
No matter who can vight.
God ble≈ø≈øe us! What a world is here,
It can ne're la≈øt another year,
Vor ich can't be able to zoe:
Do≈øt think that ever chad the art,
To plow the ground up with my cart,
My bea≈øts be all a go.
But vur≈øt a Warrant ich will get
From Ma≈øter Captaine, that a vet
Chill make a ≈øhrewd a do:
Vor then chave power in any place,
To ≈øteal a Hor≈øe without di≈øgrace,
And beat the owner too.
Ich had zix oxen tother day,
And them the Roundheads vetcht away,
A mi≈øchiefe be their ≈øpeed:
And chad zix hor≈øes left me whole,
And them the Cabbaleroes ≈øtole:
Chee voor men be agreed,
Here ich doe labour, toyl and zweat,
And dure the cold, with dry and heat,
And what do≈øt think ich get?
Vaith ju≈øt my labour vor my pains,
The garri≈øons have all the gains,
Vor thither all's avet.
There goes my corne and beanes, and pea≈øe,
Ich doe not dare them to di≈øplea≈øe,
They doe zo zwear and vapour:
When to the Governour ich doe come,
And pray him to di≈øcharge my zum,
Chave nothing but a paper.
U'ds nigs do≈øt think that paper will
Keep warme my back and belly fill?
No, no, goe vange thy note:
If that another year my vield
No profit doe unto me yeild,
Ich may goe cut my throat.
When any money chove in ≈øtore,
Then ≈øtraight a warrant comes therefore,
Or ich mu≈øt blundred be:
And when chave ≈øhuffled out one pay,
Then comes another without delay,
Was ever the leek azee?
If all this be not grief enow,
They have a thing cald quarter too,
O'ts a vengeance wa≈øter:
A pox upon't they call it vree,
Cham zure they make us zlaves to be,
And every rogue our ma≈øter.
I Keep my Hor≈øe, I keep my Whore,
I take no Rents, yet am not poore,
I traver≈øe all the land about,
And yet was born to never a foot;
With Partridge plump, and Woodcock fine,
I do at mid-night often dine;
And if my whore be not in ca≈øe,
My Ho≈øte≈øs daughter has her place.
The maids ≈øit up, and watch their turnes,
If I ≈øtay long the Tap≈øter mourns;
The Cook-maid has no mind to ≈øin,
Though tempted by the Chamberlin;
But when I knock, O how they bu≈øtle;
The ho≈øtler yawns, the geldings ju≈øtle;
If maid be ≈øleep, oh how they cur≈øe her!
And all this comes of, Deliver your pur≈øe ≈øir.
THere is not half ≈øo warme a fire
In the Fruition, as De≈øire.
When I have got the fruit of pain,
Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion makes me poore again,
Expected formes and ≈øhapes unknown,
Whet and make ≈øharp tentation;
Sen≈øe is too niggardly for Bli≈øs,
And payes me dully with what is;
But fancy's liberall, and gives all
That can within her va≈øtne≈ø≈øe fall;
Vaile therefore ≈øtill, while I divine
The Trea≈øure of this hidden Mine,
And make Imagination tell
What wonders doth in Beauty dwell.
FUller of wi≈øh, than hope, methinks it is‚ñ™
For me to expect a fuller work than this,
Fuller of matter, fuller of rich ≈øen≈øe,
Fuller of Art fuller of Eloquence;
Yet dare I not be bold, to intitle this
The fulle≈øt work; the Author fuller is,
Who, though he empty not him≈øelf, can fill
Another fuller, yet continue ≈øtill
Fuller him≈øelf, and ≈øo the Reader be
Alwayes in hope a fuller work to ≈øee.

div.head: On a Sheepherd that died for Love.

lg.l: CLoris, now thou art fled away,

l.hi: Shee's gone, ≈øhee's gone, and he alway,

div.head: The Shepheards lamentation for the lo≈ø≈øe of his Love.

lg.l: DOwn lay the Shepheards Swain,
So ≈øober and demure,
Wi≈øhing for his wench again,
So bonny and ≈øo pure.
With his head on hillock low,
And his armes on kembow;
And all for the lo≈ø≈øe of her Hy nonny nonny no.
His teares fell as thin,
As water from a Still,
His haire upon his chin,
Grew like tyme upon a hill:
His cherry cheeks were pale as ≈ønow,
Te≈øtifying his mickle woe;
And all was for the lo≈øs of her hy nonny nonny no.
Sweet ≈øhe was, as fond of love,
As ever fettred Swaine;
Never ≈øuch a bonny one
Shall I enjoy again.
Set ten thou≈øand on a row,
Ile forbid that any ≈øhow
Ever the like of her, hy nonny nonny no.
Fac'd ≈øhe was of Filbard hew,
And bo≈øom'd like a Swanne:
Back't ≈øhe was of bended yew,
And wa≈øted by a ≈øpan.
Haire ≈øhe had as black as Crow,
From the head unto the toe,
Down down all over, hy nonny nonny no.
With her Mantle tuckt up high,
She foddered her Flocke,
So bucke≈øome and alluringly,
Her knee upheld her ≈ømock;
So nimbly did ≈øhe u≈øe to goe,
So ≈ømooth ≈øhe danc'd on tip-toe,
That all men were fond of her, hy nonny nonny no.
She ≈øimpred like a Holy-day,
And ≈ømiled like a Spring,
She pratled like a Popinjay,
And like a Swallow ≈øing.
She tript it like a barren Doe,
And ≈øtrutted like a Gar-crowe:
Which made me ≈øo fond of her, hy, &c.
To trip it on the merry Down,
To dance the lively Hay,
To wra≈øtle for a green Gown,
In heat of all the day,
Never would ≈øhe ≈øay me no.
Yet me thought ≈øhe had though
Never enough of her, hy, &c.
But gone ≈øhe is the blithe≈øt La≈ø≈øe
That ever trod on Plain.
What ever hath betided her,
Blame not the Shepheard Swain.
For why, ≈øhe was her own foe,
And gave her ≈øelfe the overthrowe,
By being too franke of her hy nonny nonny no.

div.head: A Ballad on Queen Elizabeth;
div.opener: to the tune of Sallengers round.

lg.l: I Tell you all both great and ≈ømall,
And I tell you it truely,
That we have a very great cau≈øe,
Both to lament and crie,
Oh fie, oh fie, oh fie, oh fie,
Oh fie on cruell death;
For he hath taken away from us
Our Queen Elizabeth.
He might have taken other folk,
That better might have been mi≈øt,
And let our gratious Queen alone,
That lov'd not a Popi≈øh Prie≈øt.
She rul'd this Land alone of her ≈øelf,
And was beholding to no man.
She bare the waight of all affaires,
And yet ≈øhe was but a woman.
A woman ≈øaid I? nay that is more
Nor any man can tell,
So cha≈øte ≈øhe was, ≈øo pure ≈øhe was,
That no man knew it well.
For whil≈øt that ≈øhe liv'd till cruel death
Expo≈øed her to all.
Wherefore I ≈øay lament, lament,
Lament both great and ≈ømall.
She never did any wicked thing,
Might make her con≈øcience prick her,
And ≈øcorn'd for to ≈øubmit her ≈øelf to him
That calls him≈øelf Chri≈øts Vicker:
But rather cho≈øe couragiou≈øly
To fight under Chri≈øts Banner,
Gain≈øt Turk and Pope, I and King of Spain,
And all that dur≈øt with≈øtand her.
She was as Cha≈øte and Beautifull,
And Faire as ere was any;
And had from forain Countreys ≈øent
Her Suters very many.
Though Moun≈øieur came him≈øelf from France,
A purpo≈øe for to woe her,
Yet ≈øtill ≈øhe liv'd and dy'd a Maid,
Doe what they could unto her.
And if that I had Argus eyes,
They were too few to weep,
For our ≈øweet Queen Elizabeth,
Who now doth lye a≈øleep:
A ≈øleep I ≈øay ≈øhe now doth lye,
Untill the day of Doome:
But then ≈øhall awake unto the di≈øgrace
Of the proud Pope of Rome.

div.head: A Ballad on King James;
div.opener: to the tune of When Arthur fir≈øt in Court began.

lg.l: WHen James in Scotland fir≈øt began,
And there was crowned King,

All in his clouts ≈øwadling.
But when he waxed into yeares,
And grew to be ≈øomewhat tall,
And told his Lords, a Parliament
He purpo≈øed to call.
That's over‚ñ™ much quoth Douglas though,
For thee to doe I feare,
For I am Lord Protector yet,
And will be one halfe yeare.
It plea≈øeth me well, quoth the King,
What thou ha≈øt ≈øaid to me,
But ≈øince thou ≈øtande≈øt on ≈øuch tearmes,
Ile prove as ≈øtrict to thee.
And well he rul'd and well he curb'd
Both Douglas and the re≈øt;
Till Heaven with better Fortune and Power,

Then into England ≈øtraight he came
As fa≈øt as he was able,
Where he made many a Carpet Knight,

And when he entered Barwicke Town,
Where all in peace he found:
But when that roaring Megge went off,
His Grace was like to ≈øwound.
Then up to London ≈øtraight he came,
Where he made no long ≈øtay,
But ≈øoon returned back again,
To meet his Queen by th' way.
And when they met, ≈øuch tilting was,
The like was never ≈øeen;
The Lords at each others did run,
And neer a tilt between.
Their Hor≈øes backs were under them,
And that was no great wonder,
The wonder was to ≈øee them run,
And break no Staves in ≈øunder.
They ran full ≈øwift and coucht their Speares,
O ho quoth the Ladies then,
They run for ≈øhew, quoth the people though,
And not to hurt the men.
They ≈ømote full hard at Barriers too,
You might have heard the ≈øound,
As farre as any man can goe,
When both his legges are bound.
THe Chandler grew neer his end,
Pale Death would not ≈øtand his friend;
But tooke it in ≈øoul ≈ønuff,
As having tarryed long enough:
Yet left this not to be forgotten,
Death and the Chandler could not cotton.
FArre in the Forre≈øt of Arden,
There dwelt a Knight hight Ca≈ø≈øimen,
As bold as I≈øenbras:
Fell he was and eager bent
In battaile and in Turnament,
As was the good Sr. Topas.
He had (as Antique ≈øtories tell)
A daughter cleped Dow≈øabell,
A Maiden faire and free,
Who, cau≈øe ≈øhe was her fathers heire,
Full well ≈øhe was y-tought the leire
Of mickle courte≈øie.
The Silke well could ≈øhe twi≈øt and twine,
And make the fine Marchpine,
And with the needle work.
And ≈øhe could help the Prie≈øt to ≈øay
His Mattins on a Holy-day,
And ≈øing a P≈øalme in Kirk.
Her Frocke was of the frolique Green,
(Mought well become a Mayden Queen)
Which ≈øeemely was to ≈øee:
Her Hood to it was neat and fine,
In colour like the Columbine,
y-wrought full ‚Ä¢ eatuou≈øly.
This Maiden in a morne betime,
Went forth when May was in her prime,
To get ≈øweet Scettuall,
The Hony ≈øuckle, the Horelock,
The Lilly, and the Ladies-Smock,
To dight her ≈øummer Hall.
And as ≈øhe romed here, and there,
Y-picking of the bloomed brier,
She chanced to e≈øpie
A Shepheard ≈øitting on a bank,
Like Chanticleere he crowed crank,
And pip'd with merry glee.
He leerd his Sheep as he him li≈øt,
When he would whi≈øtle in his fi≈øt,
To feed about him round,
Whil≈øt he full many a Caroll ≈øung,
That all the fields, and meadowes rung,
And made the woods re≈øound.
In favour this ≈øame Shepheard Swaine
Was like the Bedlam Tamerlaine,
That kept proud Kings in awe.
But meek he was as meek mought be,
Yea like the gentle Abell, he
Whom his lewd brother ≈ølew.
This Shepheard ware a freeze-gray Cloake,
The which was of the fine≈øt locke,
That could be cut with Sheere:
His Aule and Lingell in a Thong,
His Tar-box by a broad belt hung,
His Cap of Minivere.
His Mittens were of Bau≈øons skin,
His Cockers were of Cordowin,
His Breech of country blew:
All curle, and cri≈øped were his Locks,
His brow more white then Albion Rocks:
So like a Lover true.
And piping he did ≈øpend the day,
As merry as a Popinjay,
Which lik'd faire Dow≈øabell,
That wod ≈øhe ought, or wod ≈øhe nought,
The Shepheard would not from her thought,
In love ≈øhe longing fell:
With that ≈øhe tucked up her Frock,
(White as the Lilly was her Smock,)
And drew the Shepheard nigh,
But then the Shepheard pip'd a good,
That all his Sheep for ≈øook their food,
To heare his melody.
Thy Sheep (quoth ≈øhe) cannot be lean,
That have ≈øo faire a Shepheard Swain,
That can his Pipe ≈øo well:
I but (quoth he) the Shepheard may,
If Piping thus he pine away,
For love of Dow≈øabell.
Of love (fond boy) take thou no keep,
Look well (quoth ≈øhe) unto thy Sheep;
Le≈øt they ≈øhould chance to ≈øtray.
So had I done (quoth he) full well,
Had I not ≈øeen faire Dow≈øabell,
Come forth to gather May.
I cannot ≈øtay (quoth ≈øhe) till night,

Yet are you, quoth he, too unkind,
If in your heart you cannot find,
To love us now and then.
And I will be to thee as kind,
As Collin was to Ro≈øalinde,
Of courte≈øie the flower.
And I will be as true (quoth ≈øhe)
As ever Lover yet mought be,
